title_review: Great place, food is a hit or miss tho
review_preview: A nice place with a good atmosphere in the center of Madrid. It attracts a very mixed crowd and that makes it fun. Food wise it's a mixed bag: the eggplant slices with honey and sea salt were delicious, the burger was a mess. I...
review_full: A nice place with a good atmosphere in the center of Madrid. It attracts a very mixed crowd and that makes it fun. Food wise it's a mixed bag: the eggplant slices with honey and sea salt were delicious, the burger was a mess. I had to send mine back twice. The first one was burned, the second was undercooked. The third time they got it right. A shame for such a nice place! Service provided by the staff is friendly and correct tho their knowledge of English isn't great. Recommended but keep an eye on your burger.

It felt slightly wrong to have burgers instead of tapas while in Spain but in this case we were glad we did as they were cooked to perfection (rare just how we like) with delicious cheese and chorizo on top, possibly one of the most tasty burgers I've had. We also had dessert and wine and overall it was pretty reasonably priced - we really enjoyed our meal here.

review_preview: We booked this restaurant for our last night in Madrid as we were craving some Asian food after overdosing on tapas, and we were not disappointed. Sure, it's a tad expensive, but the old adage of 'you get what you pay for' applies here. They...
review_full: We booked this restaurant for our last night in Madrid as we were craving some Asian food after overdosing on tapas, and we were not disappointed. Sure, it's a tad expensive, but the old adage of 'you get what you pay for' applies here. They had Toro (tuna belly) on the menu which is super hard to find in most sushi places, and the black cod in miso was to die for. For sushi fans, you'll be glad to know that they had real, freshly grated wasabi as well. The only slight minus was the beef fillet. Not that it was bad - it was good, but stopped just short of being great. I suppose we are spoilt rotten being from London and having easy access to Aberdeen Angus beef. You definitely won't get better Japanese food in Madrid though, their ranking is more than justified!

review_preview: I dropped in here 26 of September. Was fully booked online, but thought they might have room for 1 person as they usually can find a spot and they did. I ordered the Spicy tuna tartar and the Miyama style sushi. Tartar was nice but...
review_full: I dropped in here 26 of September. Was fully booked online, but thought they might have room for 1 person as they usually can find a spot and they did.  I ordered the Spicy tuna tartar and the Miyama style sushi. Tartar was nice but not spicy at all, but ok. No complaints still, it was a good tartar. The Miyama style sushi is "grilled" or flambed and had a very nice taste. Good rice. Served without wasabi and soy sauce but it was no problem. I guess it was what they wanted. The maki roll was something I hadn't had before. It was like curry tasting, but it was with fish. Anyway it was new and pleasent. Very nice. The chop sticks are the cheap type wich you break apart, not their own high quality sticks, and the locale is not upscale, but absolutely fine. Good selection of wines. The waiters struggle with english, but here in spain it seems most people aren't up tp speed on the worlds #1 international language. I managed to order what I wanted with poining and gesturing.

review_preview: We decided to try out this restaurant based on everyone's comments and we were not disappointed ! We went on a tuesday evening without any reservation and it was full ! The waiter kindly managed to find us a table though. This is indeed more...
review_full: We decided to try out this restaurant based on everyone's comments and we were not disappointed ! We went on a tuesday evening without any reservation and it was full ! The waiter kindly managed to find us a table though.  This is indeed more expensive than the usual japanese restaurants but it is definetely of a higher standard - they change plates sticks etc with every dish, the service is perfect and the food quality is just amazing and super fresh. We were a tiny bit disappointed by the rolls though as the sauce was a bit too tasty and hided the rest of the ingredients. We tried the roadted eggplant which was good, sashimi mix (tuna belli was to die), and two types of special californians maki.  Tried out the green tea dessert where the chesnut did not add much but the mix between green tea and passion fruit was amazing.  Perfect for a romantic date or for a family reunion.

title_review: Excellent break from tapas while in Madrid
review_preview: My husband and I were in Spain for almost 2 weeks when we finally decided we were tired of tapas.  We looked on trip advisor for a good sushi restaurant and found this one.  The food was of excellent quality and very well presented.  It...
review_full: My husband and I were in Spain for almost 2 weeks when we finally decided we were tired of tapas. We looked on trip advisor for a good sushi restaurant and found this one. The food was of excellent quality and very well presented. It was a bit pricey but okay for sushi and for the quality of food received. The wait staff is extremely friendly and professional but it times it seems they are too attentive. They are so quick to grab your plate or cup when you are finished that you feel like you're never really alone with your companion. It also feels like they have too many waiters for that size of a restaurant. The restaurant and bathroom were super clean and it was great to watch the chef make the sushi from our seat at the bar. Overall a great experience, we would recommend it to other visitors of Madrid looking for an alternative to tapas.

review_preview: I have lived in Japan for a while and I was blown away the first time I visited Miyama. The sushi is of EXCELLENT quality and reasonably priced compared to some other restaurants in Madrid. The nigiris are just perfect - with generous pieces of...
review_full: I have lived in Japan for a while and I was blown away the first time I visited Miyama. The sushi is of EXCELLENT quality and reasonably priced compared to some other restaurants in Madrid. The nigiris are just perfect - with generous pieces of fresh fish and just a little bit of rice. The staff are mainly (if not all) Japanese, and I saw a lot of Japanese clientele there. Definitely recommended (and in my view far better than Ginza, which I felt was v expensive with average sushi).

I would recommend this place to anyone in the area interested in trying something different. It was a bit on the pricey side but on par with what I would expect to pay for a meal of that level. Overall we would absolutely come back, this place is a hidden gem in a neighborhood that feels like they can't wait to rip off tourists.

review_preview: We have been in Madrid a month and this is our round the corner go to place for delicious food and wine. It is a local deli as well so you can also get take out. Huge choice of local cheeses and jamon. Gets very...
review_full: We have been in Madrid a month and this is our round the corner go to place for delicious food and wine. It is a local deli as well so you can also get take out. Huge choice of local cheeses and jamon. Gets very busy at Spanish lunch and dinner hours but this adds to the great atmosphere. Popped in at midnight a few times and still full. The staff are welcoming and if needed there is an English version of the menu. Delicious coffe and tomato tostado in the morning. The tostado with mushroom and parmesan topping, and the one with melted cheese and tomato pesto are both delicious, also the spinach salad with walnuts, cheese and a divine mustard dressing. A meat eating friend approved of the jamon iberico. We always share as the portions are generous. There is a board with good wine offerings by the glass or you can buy a bottle of the more expensive wines off the rack to take away, or drink it there and there is a corkage fee. Excellent value. Make sure you go early on in your Madrid trip so that you can go back.

review_preview: Booked our table for lunch. Got the confirmation by e-mail. In the confirmation there was nothing about the dress code. As it was lunchtime and that weekend was a heatwave in Madrid with 42 degrees Celsius my partner put a dark blue golf bermuda pants...
review_full: Booked our table for lunch. Got the confirmation by e-mail. In the confirmation there was nothing about the dress code. As it was lunchtime and that weekend was a heatwave in Madrid with 42 degrees Celsius my partner put a dark blue golf bermuda pants and linen shirt on. When we arrived to the restaurant we were right away informed that we can`t enter as my partner´s outfit was not acceptable. They are entitled to their own rules, but at least they could inform customers when booking. In a situation like this they should have looked for some solution, offering to hold our table until we go and buy a pair of long pants, trying to reschedule our table etc. Instead we were treated like dirt by the really rude and stuck-up maitre. We are regulars in many very high quality restaurants and we know how to dress up. This behaviour is derogatory to the restaurant and the great traditions of Santi Santamaria. We were really humiliated. Even though this restaurant was on our bucket list, we will make sure not to return at any time in the future.

review_full: In Madrid for a business trip, I was invited to this 2-star restaurant by my hosts (which I deeply thank !!). The restaurant opens exactly at 9pm and serves a sumptuous 13 course tasting menu, not including the 5 different amuse-bouches we were offered at the beginning. We paired the menu with the Spanish wines and it was a very good thing, since the choice of the 7 wines (and one beer) is really great. Two courses were unforgettable indeed: the cheese tray (amazing selection and vry balanced choice - matching that of top French restaurants) and the smoked ricotta ravioli with Petrossian caviar, a taste most unique ! Worth the detour and the money !

title_review: The best seat in the house, good food and wine - perfect....
review_preview: We commenced our visit in the bar of the hotel before heading down into the basement and to, what is, the tastefully decorated, comfortable, relaxed and unpretentious restaurant that is Santceloni.With its excellent service throughout from food to wine, this restaurant certainly has an...
review_full: We commenced our visit in the bar of the hotel before heading down into the basement and to, what is, the tastefully decorated, comfortable, relaxed and unpretentious restaurant that is Santceloni. With its excellent service throughout from food to wine, this restaurant certainly has an air of class and seated at, what must be, the best seat in the house (the chef’s table) with an excellent view of the kitchen and the large team within, we were fortunate enough to be afforded a constant view of their preparations, which they undertook continuously in a relaxed and organised fashion working in unison to prepare exemplary dishes, of the highest standard and finest quality, course after course.  We opted for the taster menu, each dish perfectly portioned allowing you to enjoy the entire 13 courses. Taken with the accompanying Spanish wine selection we found that we were presented with perfect food and wine combinations throughout the meal, which allowed us to benefit magnificently from our gastronomic experience. Having to choose a favourite, and least favourite, dish is nigh on impossible as there was nothing I did not favour, from start to finish. However, I will endeavor to try by saying that least would have to be Maresme peas and best would have been the goat shoulder. The well designed menu is interesting and varied and the excellent team in the kitchen crafted it perfectly in such a way that its creator could surely not fail to be proud of,  Santceloni serves up the best cheese board I have ever seen and this would be a selection any cheese lover would die for and each of our assisted Spanish varieties were amazing. Excellence is the key word at Santceloni and the desserts, along with dessert wines, and amazing petit fours followed on in the same vein as the previous service and dishes and I was served an excellent brandy Alexander. With its impeccable service and food, Santceloni was heading for my overall number one but unfortunately, the final meal of our stay has pushed it into a joint number one position both holders, of which, now hail from this magnificent city. Santceloni is well worthy of its 2 stars and more. We had the most wonderful evening’s dining in a restaurant that takes pride in its exceptional standards and I would have no hesitation, from our visit alone, to award the highest recommendation as a definite ‘must try’ and, in my opinion, it would be remiss to visit Madrid without enjoying the delights that Santceloni has to offer. Thank you to everyone who were involved in making our visit so fantastic.

We did not order the wine pairing, just a couple of glasses that were superb, but instead split a cheese course. The latter was brought out on a huge antediluvian-looking and very heavy wooden bench literally overflowing with the best cheeses of Spain and beyond.  Yes, the meal is pricey, but it was one of the better gastronomical experiences we've had. Highly recommended.

review_preview: We finally found some really good sushi in Madrid....but at a price.  I'd definitely go again, but this is more of a special occasion place (2-3 times a year) versus a monthly treat.  It's very nice inside and the service was great.  Our waitress spoke...
review_full: We finally found some really good sushi in Madrid....but at a price. I'd definitely go again, but this is more of a special occasion place (2-3 times a year) versus a monthly treat. It's very nice inside and the service was great. Our waitress spoke English and they have an English menu. We went for lunch (must make reservations, do it online, it's easy). For our starters, I got the salmon tartare and my husband got the tuna tartare. The tuna tartare was the winner there. For our main course, I got the traditional sushi platter (8 different pieces of sushi and a 6-piece tuna roll) and my husband got the chef's selection (10 different pieces of sushi). Everything was fresh and delicious, especially the fatty tuna. We split a dessert (mochi w/ ice cream & berries) which was also very good. All this, plus 2 beers, 1 coffee, and 1 glass of wine came to 85 euro. Next time I'll have to try their tasting menu.

review_preview: We have been using “the fork” for many years and have been happy to book under whatever conditions are laid out when making the reservation. Tonight for the first time the restaurant decided to make up their own rules as to what the discount applied...
review_full: We have been using “the fork” for many years and have been happy to book under whatever conditions are laid out when making the reservation. Tonight for the first time the restaurant decided to make up their own rules as to what the discount applied to and what not !!! The offer was 40% off the A la carte ... without restrictions (menu and drinks not included) but when the time came to pay they did not honour this. Some things seemed to be eligible for discount and some not !!? After some discussions they did give the discount off all food ! To be honest we had had a very nice evening ! Restaurant is pleasant, service excellent, and food pretty good ! But ruined by what we felt was an attempt to cheat us. It’s not about the money, it’s just about honouring an agreement! I have subsequently read through other reviews and see that there seems to be consistent issues with giving the agreed fork discount. Sorry but we will not return !!! Lots of other honest Indian restaurants to try in Madrid !!

title_review: Quick Lunch near to the Office
review_preview: I have visited this place yesterday afternoon for a quick Lunch.Not a good reception, felt rude. The Ambience was nice. Seating in the sofa was very very uncomfortable. Ordered from Menu of the day.Took a lot of time to get the starters, 2...
review_full: I have visited this place yesterday afternoon for a quick Lunch. Not a good reception, felt rude.  The Ambience was nice.  Seating in the sofa was very very uncomfortable.  Ordered from Menu of the day. Took a lot of time to get the starters, 2 chicken samosas. The taste was below average.  After a while came the Lamb kofta, which too was not that great... It lacked spice and seemed to be made as a sweet dish.  The Naan (pan hindu or Indian bread ) was very bad. It was more crunchy than soft.  I felt as if I was having a papa (pappadum) rather than a naan. It was way too difficult to eat.  As I was already late, I had to skip the dessert.  My recommendation : If you are into Indian food or if you are from India, Doli is not at all recommended.   If you are trying Indian food and would like it to be bit modified as European, you can visit it. And may like it.  Also please visit in leisure, they take longer time to serve you.  Bon Appetite.

review_preview: The first of three 2 star Michelin restaurants we visited in Madrid, Santceloni is situated in the basement of the Hesperia Hotel. From the moment you enter the restaurant oozes class and expense accounts. As we were fairly tired from our journey we decided not...
review_full: The first of three 2 star Michelin restaurants we visited in Madrid, Santceloni is situated in the basement of the Hesperia Hotel. From the moment you enter the restaurant oozes class and expense accounts. As we were fairly tired from our journey we decided not to take the tasting menu (175 Euros) but opted for the wide ranging A La Carte instead.  Tables are massive and the chairs sublimely comfortable and there are wonderfully decorative place settings.  There were plenty of appetisers and excellent selection of bread with olive oil and all in all some high class dishes well presented with excellent tastes and textures without being quite "cutting edge". Presentation throughout was first class and although we did not have it the two cheese tables looked fabulous! Staff are formally dressed and overall the place was rather smart, the wine list is very comprehensive although a little on the expensive side compared to the other 2 star establishments we visited. Overall the cost was 385 Euros for three courses, a bottle of the wonderful Kripta Cava from Augusto Torello (which comes in an amphora shaped bottle), mineral water and coffee and this is very much at top pricing and more expensive than other such rated establishments.  Nonetheless we had a most enjoyable evening.

Wonderful wine lists & a relaxed atmosphere - no music, just the quiet chatter of other diners. We would love to return to try the tasting menu. Thanks for a very special evening.

review_preview: Went for the full on 160 euro tasting menu, plus 90 euros for the paired wines.  Well worth it.  Subtle, complex cooking, full of slightly understated fireworks, with polished service and some wonderful wines.  We had it for lunch, which meant 3 hours or so...
review_full: Went for the full on 160 euro tasting menu, plus 90 euros for the paired wines. Well worth it. Subtle, complex cooking, full of slightly understated fireworks, with polished service and some wonderful wines. We had it for lunch, which meant 3 hours or so of dedicated dining. You have to be in the mood for that sort of thing, and willing to pay the high prices, but if you like Michelin style fine dining, this is an excellent place. Very discreet and perhaps slightly leaning to the stuffy and expense-account crowd (whereas Ramon Freixa, which we also tried, had a slightly younger and more relaxed vibe). But wonderful. They were happy to change the menu for my partner, who does not eat meat. The cheese board was especially memorable, and they were generous with it.

review_preview: Santceloni was not our first choice for restaurants in Madrid but we were not able to get in to some we had hoped for. We were very happy that this ended up being our main event in Madrid as it is everything we hoped to...
review_full: Santceloni was not our first choice for restaurants in Madrid but we were not able to get in to some we had hoped for. We were very happy that this ended up being our main event in Madrid as it is everything we hoped to experience in a restaurant here. From the minute you walk in, you know you're in for a treat. The staff are super friendly and helpful, the room is beautiful and the food was exquisite. We chose the chef's menu so we could try a wide range of dishes. The dishes look amazing and the staff explain all the dishes so you know exactly what to expect. We went on a Monday so there were only 2 other tables which meant that the service was probably even better than usual. Every dish was delicious and it is hard to pick a favourite: the starters ( and there were about 5) were amazing and the young goat was tender and came with perfect accompaniment of pumpkin and hazelnut. A surprise for me was the eel and chicken soup - delicious and without the overpowering eel flavour that I find in many eel dishes. Of the 3 desserts, the tea slushy with mint and yogurt icecream was the pick for me - a bit of a palate cleanser after a big meal. A few people have mentioned the cheese tables which are definitely impressive and the waiters select the cheeses that they feel will suit the diner's palate - which they did perfectly. I am the only wine drinker and requested the sommelier choose a couple of wines to match and this was also a perfect match for me. Husband ordered his standard whiskey sour and the cocktail bar and waiter come to the table to shake it up. He was the highlight - super enthused and worth a cocktail just for him. This was a perfect end to our days in Madrid and we loved the meal and the experience at Santceloni - definitely recommend this for anyone who wants to experience high end dining, service and a beautiful space. Loved it.

The bread and olive oil were amazing. For appetizer, they told me they could give me two half appetizers as opposed to one appetizer. The smoked ravioli and the grilled cray fish were amazing. Then, I got their White Veal Knuckle and they brought it to me on a board and cut it for me. My only regret was that I did not leave enough room for cheese after my meal (the olive oil and bread was so good before my meal). If you are a food lover, you have to visit this place in Madrid.

review_preview: this may have been a nice restaurant once that has faded into mediocrity and still trading on its good name.the food was unremarkable. every dish was solidly okay, but not especially flavorful or inventive.the service was almost a bit rushed and obsequious (some...
review_full: this may have been a nice restaurant once that has faded into mediocrity and still trading on its good name. the food was unremarkable. every dish was solidly okay, but not especially flavorful or inventive. the service was almost a bit rushed and obsequious (some people like that maybe?). Oddly the sommelier was one guy rushing about from table to table, bringing the glassware himself after the course had arrived, then rushing off to find the bottle and able to spend no more than a hurried naming of the wine before rushing off to be late to another table. The standout dish was the delicious cheese cart at the end of the meal. They have an very good cheese buyer, but it's hardly a reason to dine here. The same month I dined at Santceloni i had a much more memorable experience at Ricard Camarena's restaurant, where everything from the staff to the service to the dishes were truly excellent, inventive, flavorful, surprising, and joyful.

title_review: Distinctive and high standard of service, excellent food.
review_preview: We selected à la carte items instead of the gastronomic menu (which takes about 3 hours). Nice decor although without any view as it is below ground level. The service was particularly attentive and distinctive. In addition to the personal touch, it was clear that...
review_full: We selected à la carte items instead of the gastronomic menu (which takes about 3 hours). Nice decor although without any view as it is below ground level. The service was particularly attentive and distinctive. In addition to the personal touch, it was clear that all top level standards were well known and followed. In addition to the ordered food, a string of miniature aperitifs and later petit fours, kept coming. While the food quality was irreproachable, in case of the fish I ordered (sole), the filets were slightly undercooked. Cost per pax ended up to be 165 euros per person.  In summary  Service: 5/5 (exceptional vs expectations or competition) Food quality: 4/5 (superior) Value: 2/5 (below average) simply owing to the price level i.e. experience costs about 3x cost/pax of a chic restaurant in the city, while overall food and service cannot be said to be 3x better, even though very high standards are maintained, particularly with regard to service.

review_preview: My wife and i just returned from a week's vacation in Madrid. We rented an apartment, as it turns out, just a few blocks away from this wonderful establishment. On our first night in town we wandered around the neighborhood to get our bearings. There...
review_full: My wife and i just returned from a week's vacation in Madrid. We rented an apartment, as it turns out, just a few blocks away from this wonderful establishment. On our first night in town we wandered around the neighborhood to get our bearings. There was a certain vibe that exuded from the walls and windows of Quiroga. We stopped in for what was our first of three visits during the week! The staff is cheery but not nosey. The food and beverages were spectacular. We ordered their house wines and were floored by their price point for value. We tried a number of their tintos that were Syrahs and Temperanios. A favorite tapas was called 'Gildas'. It was a stick that pierced a number of olives, peppers, dried tomatoes and anchovies. Flavorful but not salty. Great selection of cheeses and thin sliced Jamones. From their shelves we purchased chocolates and olive oils.  Stop by and immerse yourself in a friendly, flavorful bite of Madrid!

Food was just fantastic and truly indian taste, what we didn't get before nowhere in Europe, only at our visits of India. Our order was black Dahl, Chicken Curry, Fish Biriyani, bowel of rice and two portions of bread. We got also extra from the Chef to try chicken on red beet sause, it tasted great as well. Tasting the meals you immediately recognize that Chef is Indian. On the end we had an indian tea with milk. We have been three adults and with some water bottles we paid 70€. Portions were big. Servise was very kind and quick. We definately recommend this restaurant with real authentic indian food! Thank you very much again!

The nigirs were also very good. Nice pieces of fish and the rice were nicely cooked. The maki rolls were of varying quality. They tried to be innovative and it just did not work for all the rolls. Who wants curry on the tempura shrimp maki? It all tasted like curry! Still, their spicy tuna maki was amazing with a lovely spicy mayonnaise on the side. The service was good, the staff were fast and friendly. Still the scenery of the restaurant was only okay. A little bit old fashioned and it felt like a “cheaper” restaurant. It is more of a lunch place than a fancy dinner place in my opinion.

title_review: Great service, food was not memorable.
review_preview: Santceloni was one of 5 Michelin star restaurants we ate in Spain.    I will compare them here to give the reader perspective.   This restaurant was the first one of 5.  The five we visited were Santceloni, Diver XO, Kabuki Wellington, La terrazza del Cacino and...
review_full: Santceloni was one of 5 Michelin star restaurants we ate in Spain. I will compare them here to give the reader perspective. This restaurant was the first one of 5. The five we visited were Santceloni, Diver XO, Kabuki Wellington, La terrazza del Cacino and Lua. We did the tasting menu in all 5.  Out of all 5 we found Santceloni's food to be the least memorable. To further define, when you are served a dish from the restaurant was it so delicious that you would have a lot more of it. The answer is no. The dishes were interesting but not delicious. The Service was impeccable. Staff was friendly and did not miss a beat. The cheese course was the highlight of the night and all the cheeses were not theirs. I am not sure the restaurant deserves the second star, one for sure. I think this place was the second most expensive out of all the places we ate and I would not return there. I gave 4 stars because it is a good place, but from a Michelin restaurant it is not a good value you can do better value and taste wise in other michellin restaurants.

title_review: Creative Food, Excellent Service, Great Experience
review_preview: Santceloni was the capstone of our three week vacation through Spain and Portugal and it ended our honeymoon on a high note! The restaurant provided us with excellent service and made us feel welcome and special from the moment we arrived. One unique feature of...
review_full: Santceloni was the capstone of our three week vacation through Spain and Portugal and it ended our honeymoon on a high note! The restaurant provided us with excellent service and made us feel welcome and special from the moment we arrived. One unique feature of this restaurant was that you could view the food being made and the chefs working behind a large glass viewing area. While a bit voyeuristic, it helped you really appreciate the preparation, effort, and teamwork that the staff demonstrated and the intricacy that goes into each dish. Our server immediately provided us with water, a sommelier provided wine recommendations, and while they have an a la carte option with prices around 50E per entree, we went right for the tasting menu. The food was delicious and each dish was creatively designed and packed with flavor. We especially enjoyed the white gazpacho, duck lasagna, and lacquered white pork rib. Each of the other dishes were tasty in their own right, but these stood out in particular. Another amazing aspect of the restaurant was the cheese trolley, as two tables of cheese were carried over to us with a wide selection of Spanish and French cheeses. The staff made recommendations and then hacked off large chunks of cheese for us to try (needless to say we could not finish, but not out of lack of trying).  We also appreciated the personal service and special touch that the staff gave us. As they knew this was a special occasion, they provided my wife with a bouquet of flowers with the check.  During our trip, we had visited 9 Michelin-recognized restaurants and Santceloni ranked up there with the best. What really stood out to us was the service and the opportunity to better appreciate the chefs at their craft.

One of the cousins and his wife go there often and are treated like family, and their loyalty to the restaurant was clearly very much appreciated by the owners. The service was impeccable and the food was excellent and very creative. Lots of small plates of samplings of delicious gourmet foods. After the main dishes were served, a huge table of cheeses was presented and selections were chosen for each person individually. Also, since I was the only person whose Spanish isn’t great, one of the staff explained in English what each dish was. He was wonderful! Everyone had a wonderful time, and the “birthday girl” was presented with a birthday cake with candles. A terrific 3-hour evening.

review_preview: On this return visit, we were astounded at every aspect of Santceloni. The decor is freshened, new artwork and lighting enhance the elegant and restful atmosphere. We started with langoustines topped with an astonishingly flavorful tomato creation - perfectly cooked and melt in your mouth...
review_full: On this return visit, we were astounded at every aspect of Santceloni. The decor is freshened, new artwork and lighting enhance the elegant and restful atmosphere. We started with langoustines topped with an astonishingly flavorful tomato creation - perfectly cooked and melt in your mouth delicious. The smoked ricotta ravioli with Petrossian Osetra caviar was the perfect combination of the sweetness of the cheese and the saltiness of the roe. We shared the veal knuckle- more a shank like osso bucco. Outstanding! We opted for the cheese trolley- French and Spanish choices. Excellent and unusual tastes. The wine list is large, varied and top notch. Prices are fair, and much more reasonable than Paris or London.

review_preview: The food is excellent. Great flavours, high quality and well prepared. The tuna tartar (recommended rightly by many) is particularly good.The service is good, though a little manic: the lack of elegance of the waiting staff strikes a contrast with the elegance of the...
review_full: The food is excellent. Great flavours, high quality and well prepared. The tuna tartar (recommended rightly by many) is particularly good. The service is good, though a little manic: the lack of elegance of the waiting staff strikes a contrast with the elegance of the restaurant itself, whipping plates away and almost throwing clean ones in front of you like there was no tomorrow. (Incidentally I observed one of the waiters drinking water from a bottle in a corner of the main room which didn't particularly impress me and detracted from the impression of high class they clearly try to give). There was one small minor detail: we were "upsold" a starter - the waiter recommended a dish not on the main menu, but he did not mention the price. I don't mind spending money, but if you're offering something the customer can't see the details of, you MUST provide them. We had to ask, and accepted the proposal. A 22 euro tempura which frankly wasn't worth the price. It IS a little expensive (expect upwards of around 45 euro per person), but the quality does make it a good Japanese experience. Having said that, I doubt I would return or rave about it to anyone..

review_preview: We often try an Indian restaurant when on holiday, and were not disappointed here.Really helpful waiting staff, who were keen to advise and help, plus menu items with titles that English curry goers will be familiar with (the descriptions were in Spanish however), such...
review_full: We often try an Indian restaurant when on holiday, and were not disappointed here. Really helpful waiting staff, who were keen to advise and help, plus menu items with titles that English curry goers will be familiar with (the descriptions were in Spanish however), such as tikka masala or korma! We had some excellent bhaji and pakora to start, after complimentary spiced poppadoms. Then reverting to more traditional korma and tikka masala. This was accompanied by the best fried rice I've ever eaten with superbly cooked and fresh naan breads. The meal was rounded off with a complimentary mango lassi which was to die for! We booked through the fork and got 40% off. Truthfully, I don't think we would have given it 5 stars had we paid normal prices, as the food appeared very expensive. A brilliant dining experience all in all, with really well prepared and served Indian food. Check it out.

review_preview: Not sure why, but this place was so hyped by everyone who had been I was expecting something spectacular, but only got something "good".The place itself is much nicer in the bar/tapas area downstairs, but the place itself was not really clean, decorative wine...
review_full: Not sure why, but this place was so hyped by everyone who had been I was expecting something spectacular, but only got something "good". The place itself is much nicer in the bar/tapas area downstairs, but the place itself was not really clean, decorative wine bottles on the bar full of dust, the front door with loose handle and the place feels like it needs a good couple of weeks of serious maintenance. The upstairs dining area is not at all attractive, low ceilings, feels cramped. Food itself was good, the starters much better than the main. We ordered the mejillones with salsa mojo, and the tortilla with cod - both were very good. As main I ordered merluza with claims, dish was not that tasty and excessively oily.  What bothered me quite a bit was that two bottles I asked for were not available, in the end we were recommended a bottle, that was ok, but far from great. Service was irregular... So after so much hype, I was quite let down by this place. Possibly if I had just gone without so many recommendations it would have been a better experience....

That small problem aside, the dinner here was fun. Next time I'd probably just opt for the tapas bar downstairs as opposed to the dining room. Service was slow in the dining room and it was quite hot.

We expected a similar experience at Santceloni in Madrid. Not so. The restaurant is in an out-of-the-way hotel in Madrid. The atmosphere was deathly quiet, to the point of encouraging conversation at the level of a whisper. The food was disappointing for the price. We understand that the current economic conditions may have had an impact on the restaurant (three tables full out of twenty-five), but their price, service, and food quality have not adjusted accordingly.

review_preview: A visit to this restaurant should be mandatory for everyone who aspires to provide excellent service. One of the most professional and effiecient team of servers we have ever experienced. That means a lot.  On the other hand the food with prices starting at Euro...
review_full: A visit to this restaurant should be mandatory for everyone who aspires to provide excellent service. One of the most professional and effiecient team of servers we have ever experienced. That means a lot.  On the other hand the food with prices starting at Euro 50 and up per course while presented adequately lacked inspiration. Correct cooking without any ridiculous molecular inspirations so prevalent in Madrid today. It just could be brighter. All in all a nice evening or long lunch but do not expect to be blown away. To be fair wine prices are quite reasonable (the Spanish will not tolerate being ripped off on wine) but the food prices will take your breath away. Nonetheless- Recommended.

review_preview: You enter a very charming circular bar, with a few tables, but most people are standing.  The dining room is upstairs, long, dark hued, lots of wood; handsome.  The food is outstanding, for the most part.  Exceptions:  eggs and uni is too fussy; we had...
review_full: You enter a very charming circular bar, with a few tables, but most people are standing. The dining room is upstairs, long, dark hued, lots of wood; handsome. The food is outstanding, for the most part. Exceptions: eggs and uni is too fussy; we had a twenty pound John Dory that was way over cooked; we needed olive oil and lemon for some moisture. After ten days of eating jamon, at least once a day, we found the best here. We had two different micro green slads that were fantastic. The razor clams, muscles, and clams are all great individual dishes. The room fills pretty quickly, and it can be hard to get service attention, but when you do they work hard to please. The wine list is not large, but it is great; THE BEST producers for extremely modest cost, particularly in BURGUNDY. GO!

My companion chose some great anchovies to share, and an "over-greasy" mix of tempura vegetables (try the tempura down the road at Bar Platero to see how it should be done); he then chose a very tasty grilled red tuna with a few strands of green; my grilled sea bass came around 20 minutes later - and was raw inside. I send it back to the kitchen, and when it returned, dumped back on the plate, it was acceptable - just. High prices, small portions on main courses, poor attention to detail in the kitchen. I will be cautious when booking again.- they won't care too much, as it remains busy and popular, difficult to get a table.

The service was excellent since one of the waiters was Venezuelan and also maybe because we told the manager that an acquaintance of him recommended us the place. The food was superb! I had the cochinillo or suckling pig (don't imagine a full cochinillo just two very tender portions). We had Cava (Champagne) and I remember the other plates were incredible as well. I didn't find it expensive for restaurants of its type. Very traditional but with a touch of modernity. Reservation a MUST.

review_full: We went here on the suggestion of a friend who lives in Madrid. Being silly Americans we of course arrived at 1 to find out they started serving at 2. No worries as the wine selection was ample and well priced and we were able to stake out a prime location at the side corner of the bar standing up. By 2:15, the place was packed. Everything we tried was delicious but what stood out were: (a) bacon/mango salad; (b) salmon soup with ham; (c) waygu burger; (d) thin sliced beef with almonds; and (e) grilled squid. Pretty sure we were the only non-Spainards in the whole place. The bartenders were nice and understanding as we fumbled our way with our bad Span-glish. We will return.

I sunk down in the sofa so that I felt like a child almost not reaching up to the table. I asked if possible to change table and was told I could sit on a cushion, I said no thank you its fine and still suddenly it stood a man with a cushion there trying to make me sit on it. Embarrassing situation.  4. We asked for a 1/2 wine pairing volume as we always do (it's a hobby of both of us to eat good food and combine with interesting wines but we both find that we get to drunk with a full pairing so that we can't enjoy the last meals. We said that we just wanted very small quantities to try the tastes, and then water. We agreed on this but then comes the somelier. Obviously very angry and tries to talk loud and clear with us for us to understand that the volume is good...... Not a pleasant experience at all.  Became even more awkward when the lady who took the bill to us in the end of the meal pointed out that they had put one of the two wine pairings "on the house". I did not know what to say. We had only been ordering one and we only drank one. 5. The decoration of the table is tacky. Looks like it's all bought at "HM home".  So. As a summary. Foods pretty good but this is a 2 star micheline restaurant I had expected perfect service and a will to make the guests feel good.  That's not what this was.

review_preview: My husband took me here for lunch as a surprise for my 60th birthday and what a surprise it was.  From the moment we arrived the staff made us very welcome and the service was impeccable.  The restaurant is modern and new.  We opted for...
review_full: My husband took me here for lunch as a surprise for my 60th birthday and what a surprise it was. From the moment we arrived the staff made us very welcome and the service was impeccable. The restaurant is modern and new. We opted for the grand tasting menu of 14 courses with the wine paring to match. Before we actually started with our courses we had 7 small appetisers, very tasty and different. The courses were small but ample enough so you didnt feel uncomfortable. Presentation of all the courses was perfection, well seasoned and innovative. The sommelier chose excellent paring to each course and we never ran out of wine. This was a truly memorable experience and would like to thank all the staff for their hard work. It was well appreciated. We have eaten all over the world in many michelin star restaurants and I must say this has got to be up there at the top. Prices compared to London well there is no competition. Here you get value for money and not ripped off at stupid overrated celebrity prices. We will definately be back. In our opinion this establishment deserves its third michelin star at the very least.

title_review: Superb food and setting though not quite perfect
review_preview: We and another couple ordered a la carte at lunch. The 9-course tasting menu looked overwhelming and had dishes like pig ear that no one felt like trying (the tasting menu must be ordered by everyone or not at all). The tasting menu was a...
review_full: We and another couple ordered a la carte at lunch. The 9-course tasting menu looked overwhelming and had dishes like pig ear that no one felt like trying (the tasting menu must be ordered by everyone or not at all). The tasting menu was a bit over 160 euros and ordering 3 courses adds up to close to that--maybe 20 or 30 euros less, which is a rounding error in this context. First and second courses were imaginative and luscious--shaved chicken, prawns on lettuce, rounds of paté studded with pistachios. Second courses for us were four kinds of delectable fish. Everything here is perfectly seasoned--their philosophy is pure, perfect, honest food that they source directly. Each table is private and the setting is serene and beautiful. The small treats that they deliver throughout the meal are spectacular. Now the small flaws: dessert is not up to the standards of the meal (avoid the chocolate soup which made me think of Nestle's Quik made with cream). The dessert price of 26 euros (regardless of your choice) is not listed on the menu. Next time I would skip dessert and go straight to their after-meal tray of delicacies. They pushed water on us, opening four large bottles which we did not come close to finishing (and charging 20 euros for them). It seemed as though they were trying to make up for the fact that we didn't keep ordering wine as we all had to be alert later. These small imperfections keep the experience from being ideal. They would not occur at places like Celler de Can Roca or Arzak which make you feel as though they are totally on your side, not trying to gouge in any way. Guess that's what distinguishes a 3-star restaurant from a 2-star: there is no Part Two (but...) in a review.

When I see all of the other great reviews and how good the Spanish food is...I can only conclude that maybe Spanish food isn't my cup of tea.  Eating at cellar de can Roca, sant pau, and lasarte this week also. Maybe they will be better...

title_review: No reservation? Go for lunch right when it opens
review_preview: Spain is one of the more frustrating places to fight for a dinner reservation, and Taberna Laredo seems to be one of the toughest tables in town. Avoid this headache by going right when it opens at 1pm. The lunch menu has most of the...
review_full: Spain is one of the more frustrating places to fight for a dinner reservation, and Taberna Laredo seems to be one of the toughest tables in town. Avoid this headache by going right when it opens at 1pm. The lunch menu has most of the dinner menu's selection, and you can get bar seating on a first come, first serve basis. It's ideal for a party of two or three people. Just be sure to go right when it opens—within 20 minutes even the bar seating was gone and walk-ins were fighting for a table.

title_review: The Best Farm to Market Food in Madrid
review_preview: The one problem with going to this restaurant for my first lunch in Madrid is that I became spoiled and assumed this was what all food in Spain tasted like. First of all, the atmosphere is very well done; simple and chic with light wood...
review_full: The one problem with going to this restaurant for my first lunch in Madrid is that I became spoiled and assumed this was what all food in Spain tasted like. First of all, the atmosphere is very well done; simple and chic with light wood and dark walls. There is a very large selection of wines, many are wines from smaller vineyards in Spain and all are excellent. But above all....the food! You can't go wrong. The jamon is the best I had while in Spain, so definitely try a plate of jamon and lomo. Also mejillones con mojo pican, gambas rojas, and the ensaladilla rusa was amazing. I tried this at other restaurants since I liked it so much and none compared to this. Be sure to make reservations before as they can get booked up.

review_full: Our reservation was at 9:30. The dining room is upstairs so you walk through the bar first, which was quite noisy and had great energy. We shared the tuna tartare and squid which were both very good. We also shared the hake which was fair. The wine was good and the bread was also. The waiters work very hard and might need one more- they seemed to be running from table to table at times! But we felt well attended. Great people watching. The low ceiling bothered my wife a bit but otherwise the decor was very pleasant. It was a good meal, but not as great as some others we had.

title_review: Excellent Tapas in Madrid - Authentic & Vibrating

Local madrilenos are fond of this place which never disappointed me in the many years I have been going there.  One should particularly try the meat (hamburgesa) and the various tapas (fish, veggies, etc), obviously accompanying this excellent food with vino tinto (red wine). review_preview: If the food and service at the more formal restaurant upstairs are as good as they both are at the come-and-go bar downstairs, then I hope to make it up the stairs at Laredo sometime soon.  I've been to Laredo twice during my month-long holiday...
review_full: If the food and service at the more formal restaurant upstairs are as good as they both are at the come-and-go bar downstairs, then I hope to make it up the stairs at Laredo sometime soon. I've been to Laredo twice during my month-long holiday in Madrid, both times as a back-up after other wish-list places proved not open yet or closed without notice or impossibly packed and lined-up waiting, and both times I found everything at the Laredo bar to be wonderful. Great bartenders, at least one server (Pablo) whose English and charm are almost as good as his food recs, a very pleasant, attractive, and diverse crowd, bargain prices compared to the Manhattan we've lived in for three decades. In addition to the bar-freebies yesterday, I had bottled water, bread, three glasses of cava, a bowl of their "gazpacho" with jamon supreme, and a "half portion" (OMG--how much food would a full portion be?) of their tempura'd tiger prawn and asparagus bites, all of it just excellent, total tab 30E. Wow.

review_preview: We went to Le Maria for a supper during a business trip to Madrid. It was very, very good food. They do not have English menus or many waiters that know English, so ordering was pretty difficult. But the food was amazing. It's a small...
review_full: We went to Le Maria for a supper during a business trip to Madrid. It was very, very good food. They do not have English menus or many waiters that know English, so ordering was pretty difficult. But the food was amazing.  It's a small place, but very stylish. We made reservations at 9pm, when the restaurant opened for supper, and by about 10-10:30 the place was packed. You are supposed to see lots of celebrities there but we didn't (except for the ones on their memory wall).  We had a starter of baked cheese, it was very good. On the house they also brought out fried shrimp and Chorizo. The Chorizo, Argentina sausage, was by far the best. For the main course we had two different cuts of Argentina beef and one fish. (The fish was the last one on the fish section--I can't remember the name). My fish was moist and very tasty. There was an orange colored sauce under which was very smooth, not fruity. They also brought us some potato chips, but not your ordinary chips, these looked like mini pillows, fried. They were very addictive!! For desert, we ordered the doulche (something like that), which was vanilla ice cream on top of a cookie covered in chocolate. On the plate was a vanilla pudding with strips of chocolate over top. One of the best deserts I've ever had. They also brought us on the house warm apple pie with vanilla ice cream and these sherbet shooters. The shooters were the best probably.  Total for the food we ordered (one starter, 3 meals, 1 dessert, 2 waters, 1 beer, 1 glass of wine) our total was 135 Euros. A meal to remember!!

You might need to send it back to be cooked more as we did and so did the tables around us. In five minutes in comes back and we really enjoyed it...as did the people around us. They bring you bread and some great appetizers at no extra charge. They also provide complimentary small after dinner deserts and drinks which only add to the value. We spend 70 euro for two people with wine which is quite affordable given the service, ambiance and quality of the food. We always go here our last night to top off the trip!

review_preview: We were a group of 8 and had dinner at this De María restaurant (it belongs to a chain that has around 10 restaurants in Madrid). The place has a cozy environment, service is attentive but the food - we all had chuletón - didn't...
review_full: We were a group of 8 and had dinner at this De María restaurant (it belongs to a chain that has around 10 restaurants in Madrid). The place has a cozy environment, service is attentive but the food - we all had chuletón - didn't live up to my expectations. The meat was soft but not that tasty. I already had plenty chuletóns much better than this one.  Apart from my disappointment with this dish, which is usually a star-dish in a restaurant, everything else was ok: nice "soufflé" potato chips and tomato/onion salad as side orders for the chuletón and tasty starters (provoleta cheese and some small bits of some very soft grilled pork meat). We had quite a lot of food, drank a rather cheap but good red wine, some of us had a drink for starters and shared a couple of deserts. The meal costed 60 euros per person - a bit too much given the quality of the food, I'd say.
